CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, September 28, 1946, pg. 8, reads: "Lovely Bride - Miss Deane Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Curtis of Pittsburgh, was married Saturday, Sept. 21, to Ernest H. Wesley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Wesley of Charlottesville, Va., in a charming ceremony held in bride's home. The bride is a graduate of Howard University, and has been employed in Washington for the past year, while the groom is a student in Howard Dental School. - Harris Photo." Portions of accompanying article read: "Deane Curtis Is Bride of Ernest H. Wesley; Charming Home Rites Unite Popular Couple - ...united in marriage Saturday, Sept. 21...  The bridal gown was a handsome creation of ivory satin, made with a round neckline, outlined with a design of lilies and pearls.  Her finger-tip veil fell from clustered flowers over each ear, and her bouquet was of gardenias.  Mrs. Jean Curtis, pretty sister-in-law of the bride, was the sole attendant and chose rust colored faille for her gown.  Her headdress was a small brown hat trimmed with baby bronze and yellow mums and her bouquet was of the same colored mums.  Ellison is best man.  John Malcus Ellison, son of the president of Virginia Union, of Richmond, Va., was best man.  The Rev. Charles H. Foggie of Wesley Center AME church, officiated at the ceremony which was performed in the presence of relatives of the bide and groom against a background of gladoli and palms.  A reception followed immediately after the ceremony, with a marquee on the lawn for the serving of the myriad hors d'oeuvres and other refreshments.  Attending the ceremony was Mrs. Wesley, mother of the groom who wore pink crepe, with a orchid corsage.  Mrs. Curtis, the bride's mother chose geranium crepe, accented with orchids.  Guests.  Among the scores of guests who passed the receiving line from five until seven, were several out-of-towners, including Mrs. Phyllis Downing of Altoona, Pa., Miss August Bolden of Washington, D. C., Miss Marion Tate of Plainfield, N. J., Miss Marie Belle Wesley, sister of the groom, Charlottesville, Va., Pete Jackson, Buffalo, N. Y., C. A. Johnson, Washington, D. C., Mrs. Burrell Johnson of Johnstown, Pa., and Mrs. Loretta McCallister of Cincinnati, Ohio...  After a honeymoon trip to Buffalo, N. Y., the couple retuned to Washington where they are making their home for the time being.
TitMainTitle: Portrait of woman, possibly Mrs. Curtis wearing dark short sleeved crepe dress and fingerless gloves, posed in front of dark crushed velvet curtain, for Curtis - Wesley wedding in Curtis home on Ewart Drive, Upper Hill District
